name: Reference
description: A scenario where current energy policies are maintained in the Philippines.
overview:
The Philippines Department of Energy Reference scenario follows current development trends and strategies. It includes existing plants and committed power projects and WESM-registered capacities as of May 2023. It targets 35% of renewable electricity in 2030 and 50% by 2050.
It aims for an energy intensity reduction consistent with regional targets: a 10% EV adoption rate by 2040, stable biofuel blending (2%) and a 5% reduction in energy use based on energy efficiency and conservation (EEC) actions.
expertRecommendation:
The Reference scenario is a power sector pathway for the Philippines based on present development trends and strategies. This policy pathway has strong data point coverage on investment, job creation and energy supply and some quantitative insights on the direction of the Philippines transition based on current trends. As a country-level pathway, the Reference scenario does not model a global temperature rise and as such, it cannot be used to set or measure temperature aligned targets. For sector specific target setting, it may still not be ideal, as it does not model medium to long term policy trends. However, it can be useful for risk focused (or other commercial) use cases, especially when the emphasis is on current actions. The Reference scenario makes significant power market assumptions to connect power generation with other sectors and other parts of the power value chain. But this connection with the full power value chain makes it a good resource for dependency mapping for Philippines power utilities, or to better understand the market feasibility of a corporate transition plan.

#### Emissions
The emissions figures contain GHGs including CO2, CH4 and NO2. Emissions are available for the buildings, industry, and transformation sectors which includes power generation and other. Due to the assumptions and scope of the analysis, transformation emissions vary most between scenarios. Total emissions increased by 2.5% a year between 2023 and 2050 in Reference scenario. Carbon removals are out of scope for this analysis.

#### Energy demand
The scenario provides total final energy consumption, total primary energy supply and total energy supply per fuel and per sector. 

#### Supply Assumptions
Because Philippines imports most of their fossil fuel they consume, they have a strong exposure to fossil fuel price changes in international market. Investments in upstream fossil fuels is constant across scenarios.
The Reference scenario also shows some LNG imports in the short term, starting in 2023 with the projected commercial operation of seven LNG projects.
Similarly, the scenario plans some investment in oil import terminals.
The coal moratorium prevents the addition of new coal capacity in the power sector, except the one in the pipeline. Coal related emissions continue to rise until 2050.

#### Demand Shifts
Power generation demand increases by 5% annually. This is a common assumption for all scenarios published by the PH DoE.

#### Policies
The Reference scenario follows existing policies and the development trends and strategies based on what companies are planning now.

#### Technology Costs
The Reference scenario does not disclose any information on technology costs. It is possible to derive the cost of capital based on investments and added capacity, but deriving any further information, such as the LCOE, would require external assumptions.

#### Technology deployment
The Reference scenario assumes 35% renewables share in 2030 and 50% renewables share in 2050, from a 24% share in 2023. This increase is mostly due to solar and onshore wind expansion. 

#### Investment needs
Total investment requirements in the energy sector until 2050 are 357 billion USD, for upstream (fossil fuel extraction), downstream (Oil depot and terminal, LNG Terminal, EV charging station) and power generation. Investment figures are available per technology type for each part of the value chain for the period 2023-2028 and 2029-2050.
In the power sector, investment is available for coal, oil, gas, battery storage, renewables and other. Renewables investment represents 75% of total power investment in the period 2023-2050. Total investment for the power sector only covers construction of new power capacity but it does not include investments in the power grid.

#### Infrastructure requirement
The PH Department of Energy provides a list of transmission projects, with a percentage completion, and a completion target date. Those transmission projects follow the Transmission Development Plan (TDP) 2022-2040.

#### Sensitivity analysis
No sensitivity analysis is done in this baseline scenario.

name: CES1
description: Philippines Power Development Plan following NREP with low offshore wind development.
overview: The CES1 scenario forecasts more than 50% of renewables generation by 2050. Nuclear capacity is added from 2032 to achieve this, along with 19GW of offshore wind, following the NREP. CES1 also targets higher adoption of low carbon solutions: EV penetration of 50% in 2040, a 10% reduction in energy use based on energy efficiency and conservation (EEC) actions, and a 5% biofuel blending. CES1 and CES2 have the same assumptions except offshore wind buildout.
expertRecommendation:
CES1 is a policy scenario following the 2022 version of National Renewables Energy Program (NREP), with a low reliance on offshore wind. As other pathways from the Philippines Department of Energy (PH DoE), it has strong data coverage on investment, job creation and energy supply. 
As a country-level pathway, the CES1 pathway does not model a global temperature rise and as such, it cannot be used to set or measure temperature aligned targets. It can, however, be used for certain sector specific target setting, such as technology mix targets, as it models medium to long term policy trends. It can also be useful for risk focused (or other commercial) use cases, especially where future company plans are concerned.
Because NREP mostly focuses on the power development plan, the CES1 pathway makes significant assumptions to connect the NREP with other sectors and other parts of the power value chain. But this connection with the full power value chain makes it a good resource for dependency mapping for Philippines power utilities, or to better understand the market feasibility of a corporate transition plan.

#### Emissions
The CES 1 emissions figures contain GHGs including CO2, CH4 and NO2. Emissions are available for the buildings, industry, and transformation sectors which includes power generation and other. Due to the assumptions and scope of the analysis, transformation emissions vary most between scenarios, transportation emissions contribute to the variation because of increased EV use. Total emissions increase by 1.4% a year between 2023 and 2050 in CES1. 70% of the difference to the emissions in the Reference scenario in 2050 comes from transformation sector. Carbon removals are out of scope for this analysis.

#### Energy demand
The scenario provides total final energy consumption, total primary energy supply and total energy supply per fuel and per sector. 

#### Supply Assumptions
Because the Philippines import most of the fossil fuels they consume, they have a strong exposure to fossil fuel price changes in international markets. Investments in upstream fossil fuels are constant across scenarios.
The increase in biofuel blending to 5% reduces the Philippines’ dependency on international oil prices. This scenario does not foresee additional LNG imports.
Coal use significantly declines:
* in industrial process use, a 9% decline occurs due to efficiency gains.
* in power generation, coal use declines due to wind and solar capacity build out.
Still, coal-related emissions remain constant in CES1 until 2050, versus a 15% reduction in CES2.

#### Demand Shifts
Power generation increases by 5% a year in the Philippines. This demand increase is an assumption from the scenario.
In addition, the scenario assumed an EV adoption rate of 50% in 2040, and an energy efficiency and conservation effort to reduce energy demand by 10% in 2040-2050.
This is a caveat of the scenario. The power demand forecast is assumed to be constant across all PH DoE scenarios, although in the CES scenarios the shift towards EV is more pronounced and should result in an increased electricity demand.

#### Policies
Capacity additions follow the updated NREP. They include nuclear power additions from 2032 and 19GW of Offshore Wind Power by 2050.

#### Technology Costs
The Reference scenario does not disclose any information on technology costs. It is possible to derive the cost of capital based on investments and added capacity, but deriving any further information, such as the LCOE, would require external assumptions.

#### Technology deployment
Renewables generation represents 65% of power generation in CES1 in 2050, led by 32.5% of wind (16.8% offshore, 15.7% onshore) and 20% of Solar PV.
Renewables generation represents 70% in CES2 and CES1 fills the gap to 70% mostly with gas-fired power.

#### Investment needs
Total investment requirement in the energy sector is 505 billion USD until 2050. This figure includes upstream (fossil fuel extraction), downstream (oil depots and terminals, LNG terminals, EV charging stations), and power generation investment.
Investment is available for the period 2023-2028 and 2029-2050, breakdown by technology type and value chain.
Regarding power, this investment is available for coal, oil, gas, battery storage, renewables and other. Renewables investment represents 65% of total power generation investment in the period 2023-2050. Total power generation investment only covers construction of new capacity.

#### Infrastructure requirement
The PH DoE provides a list of transmission projects, with a percentage completion, and a completion target date. Those transmission projects follow the Transmission Development Plan (TDP) 2022-2040.

#### Sensitivity analysis
CES1 and CES2 are the same scenario with a sensitive analysis on offshore wind availability.
